newsitem.title: UK: Work on Iran-Turkmen gas pipeline starts this week.
newsitem.headline: Work on Iran-Turkmen gas pipeline starts this week.

text.p: Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aghazadeh will attend the inauguration of construction work on the Turkmen-Iran gas pipeline during a visit to Turkmenistan starting on Wednesday, the OPEC news agency OPECNA reported.

The agency, monitored in London, quoted a statement by Aghazadeh's office as saying the inauguration of work on the 200-km (130-mile) pipeline would take place during his visit to the Central Asian republic which ends on Thursday.
Officials have said that in the first stage, the pipeline will transport 1.5 million cubic metres of natural gas to Iran annually. Its capacity will rise later to 8.0 million cubic metres per year.
Turkmenistan, with the world's fourth largest gas reserves, said it exported more than 14 billion cubic metres of natural gas in the first six months of 1996.

Under an agreement reached earlier this year by officials of the two neighbouring Caspian states, the engineering and construction directorate of the National Iranian Refining and Distribution Company (NIRDC) was given the lion's share of the project, OPECNA said.
The NIRDC will be responsible for engineering work and also the building of desalting units and separating plants for gas liquids as well as the pipeline to the Iranian border.

The local segment of the project will involve construction of another 60 km pipeline (40 mile) system that would connect the network on the Turkmen side. A parallel pipeline with a pressure boosting station is also planned.
Turkmen President Saparmurat Niyazov visited Tehran in July to discuss joint projects, including a rail link opened in May connecting Turkmenistan's railways to Iran's Gulf ports.
Turkmenistan's natural gas output rose 18.3 percent in August to 2.34 billiion cubic metres in July.
